text.p: The Turkish lira eased to 92,875 against the dollar on Monday from 92,520 at Friday's close on banks' dollar demand, bankers said.
The central bank set its dollar rate for banks' compulsory currency transfers at 92,700 lira at the opening, up from 92,400 Friday's close.

Bankers said the banks' dollar demand remained relatively firm despite cash shortage, on expectations of speedier lira depreciation due to increasing inflation rate awaited in the last quarter of the year.
They said cash demand was strong as banks repaid the central bank a total of 36.7 trillion lira for overnight borrowing and maturing open market repos.

The central bank injected a total of 39.9 trillion lira -- 16.5 trillion lira by buying seven-day repos at an average annual rate of 73.33 percent in an open market auction and 23.4 trillion lira via overnight lending at 75 percent on the interbank.
The overnight money traded also at 74.75 percent during the day.
T-bill yields eased by around one point ahead of the Treasury's announcement of the week of t-bill auction.

The average yield on the most heavily traded May 7 paper eased to 127.70 percent from 127.97 on Friday. The second most active March 26 paper yielded 123.70 percent, down from Friday's 125.10 percent average.
The central bank said the Treasury would auction 238-day t-bills on Tuesday with Wednesday value date when 145.2 trillion lira will be cashed in from maturing t-bills.
